awd_titl_txt: The Chemistry of Aqueous Si(100) Etchants: Site-Specific Surface Reactions and the Role of Stress
awd_abstract_narration: The Analytical and Surface Chemistry (ASC) program of the Division of Chemistry supports the research project of Prof. Melissa Hines of the Department of Chemistry at Cornell University. Prof. Hines and her students will build upon their recent discovery of an anisotropic etchant that produces Si(100)surfaces with near-atomically flat morphologies and continue to develop new reactions and processes that enable the chemical control of surface morphology. They will study chemically etched Si(100) surfaces and the fundamental chemical mechanisms that control the evolution of Si(100) surface morphology during aqueous silicon etching using a combination of infrared absorption spectroscopy, scanning tunneling microscopy, and kinetic Monte Carlo simulations. The study will provide excellent training opportunities to graduate and undergraduate students in a cutting edge research field with direct relevance to high end applications in the semiconductor industry.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This research achieved a long-standing technological goal which many thought impossible: the production of atomically flat, chemically passivated and functionalized surfaces of the technologically relevant face of silicon, Si(100), using a simple aqueous solution compatible with current industrial processes. In doing so, this research also overturned much-applied fundamental understanding of silicon reactivity and provided a new target for silicon functionalization reactions, the surface silanone.

The technological importance of Si(100) cannot be overstated. The microelectronics industry is based almost exclusively on this surface. Many researchers have sought to replace the crucial silicon oxide layer in conventional electronics with a monolayer of organic molecules to form devices with integrated chemical or biological functionality. Others have sought an ideal silicon/molecule interface to use as a chemical precursor for the growth of ideal silicon/inorganic junctions for nanoelectronic, nanosensing, or energy-producing or ?storing devices. These long-sought goals have been stymied by a simple problem: the silicon surface used in industry has a high density of dangling bonds, each of which must be stably functionalized for the production of high-performance devices. This research demonstrated a path to both goals.

For over half a century, scientists have also known that many solutions rapidly etch all silicon surfaces except one. As a result of this selectivity, a silicon sphere placed into one of these solutions will transform into a polyhedron, such as a cube or an octahedron. This type of highly precise but inexpensive chemical machining has found use in diverse applications ranging from the production of ink-jet nozzles to the fabrication of nanoscale electronics. In spite of intense study, much remains unknown about these fascinating solutions, including their mechanism of action. This research provided new insights into this problem, showing that the high reactivity of a specific site on the surface leads to this geometric transformation. This result provides new insights into chemical micromachining.

This research project helped train 4 graduate and 3 undergraduate students in an area of national need. This research also lead to the development of a new spectroscopic technique that dramatically simplifies the analysis of infrared surface spectra, providing new insight into technologically relevant surfaces and interfaces.
